user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of version:
```c
static int version(void)
{
	char ver_def[16], ver_dyn[16];

	snprintf(ver_def, sizeof(ver_def), "%d.%d.%d",
		 METAL_VER_MAJOR,
		 METAL_VER_MINOR,
		 METAL_VER_PATCH);

	snprintf(ver_dyn, sizeof(ver_dyn), "%d.%d.%d",
		 metal_ver_major(), metal_ver_minor(), metal_ver_patch());

	return (strcmp(ver_def, METAL_VER) +
		strcmp(ver_dyn, metal_ver()));
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only places where pointer-to-character objects cross module/function boundaries (and thus may need const qualification) are the two strcmp call sites above; these should be inspected to confirm the types of METAL_VER and the return type of metal_ver(). Other fragments do not need investigation for Rule 8.13: the declarations 'char ver_def[16], ver_dyn[16];' are writable buffers populated by snprintf (so they must be modifiable), the snprintf calls write into those buffers (destination must be non-const), the numeric/version helper calls (metal_ver_major(), metal_ver_minor(), metal_ver_patch()) return scalar values (not pointers), and the return expression simply combines integer results — there are no other pointer declarations or pointer-to-object usages in this function that could be made const-qualified.
